Title: air passengers win new eu rights

Title: call centre users 'lose patience'
Sentence: customers trying to get through to call centres are getting impatient and quicker to hang up, a survey suggests.

Title: call centre users 'lose patience'
Sentence: once past the welcome message, callers on average hang up after just 65 seconds of listening to canned music.

Title: call centre users 'lose patience'
Sentence: the drop in patience comes as the number of calls to call centres is growing at a rate of 20% every year.

Title: call centre users 'lose patience'
Sentence: "customers are getting used to the idea of an 'always available' society," says cara diemont of it firm dimension data, which commissioned the survey.

Title: call centre users 'lose patience'
Sentence: however, call centres also saw a sharp increase of customers simply abandoning calls, she says, from just over 5% in 2003 to a record 13.3% during last year.

Title: call centre users 'lose patience'
Sentence: when automated phone message systems are taken out of the equation, where customers have to pick their way through multiple options and messages, the number of abandoned calls is even higher - a sixth of all callers give up rather than wait.

Title: call centre users 'lose patience'
Sentence: one possible reason for the lack in patience, ms diemont says, is the fact that more customers are calling 'on the move' using their mobile phones.

Title: call centre users 'lose patience'
Sentence: the surge in customers trying to get through to call centres is also a reflection of the centres' growing range of tasks.

Title: call centre users 'lose patience'
Sentence: "once a call centre may have looked after mortgages, now its agents may also be responsible for credit cards, insurance and current accounts," ms diemont says.

Title: call centre users 'lose patience'
Sentence: problems are occurring because increased responsibility is not going hand-in-hand with more training, the survey found.

Title: call centre users 'lose patience'
Sentence: in what dimension data calls an "alarming development", the average induction time for a call centre worker fell last year from 36 to just 21 days, leaving "agents not equipped to deal with customers".

Title: call centre users 'lose patience'
Sentence: this, ms diemont warns, is "scary" and not good for the bottom line either.

Title: call centre users 'lose patience'
Sentence: poor training frustrates both call centre workers and customers.

Title: call centre users 'lose patience'
Sentence: as a result, call centres have a high "churn rate", with nearly a quarter of workers throwing in the towel every year, which in turn forces companies to pay for training new staff.

Title: call centre users 'lose patience'
Sentence: resolution rates - the number of calls where a customer's query is resolved to mutual satisfaction - are running at just 50%.

Title: call centre users 'lose patience'
Sentence: when the query is passed on to a second or third person - a specialist or manager - rates rise to about 70%, but that is still well below the industry target of an 85% resolution rate.

Title: call centre users 'lose patience'
Sentence: suggestions that "outsourcing" - relocating call centres to low-cost countries like india or south africa - is to blame are wrong, ms diemont says.

Title: call centre users 'lose patience'
Sentence: there are "no big differences in wait time and call resolution" between call centres based in europe or north america and those in developing countries around the world.

Title: call centre users 'lose patience'
Sentence: "you can make call centres perform anywhere if you have good management and the right processes in place," she says.

Title: call centre users 'lose patience'
Sentence: however, companies that decide to "offshore" their operations are driven not just by cost considerations.

Title: call centre users 'lose patience'
Sentence: only 42% of them say that saving money is the main consideration when closing domestic call centre operations.

Title: call centre users 'lose patience'
Sentence: half of them argue that workers in other countries offer better skills for the money.

Title: call centre users 'lose patience'
Sentence: but not everybody believes that outsourcing and offshoring are the solution.

Title: call centre users 'lose patience'
Sentence: nearly two-thirds of all firms polled for the survey have no plans to offshore their call centres.

Title: call centre users 'lose patience'
Sentence: they give three key reasons for not making the move:

Title: call centre users 'lose patience'
Sentence: - call centre operations are part of their business "core function",

Title: call centre users 'lose patience'
Sentence: - they are worried about the risk of going abroad,

Title: call centre users 'lose patience'
Sentence: - they fear that they will damage their brand if they join the offshoring drive.

Title: call centre users 'lose patience'
Sentence: the survey was conducted by sunovate on behalf of dimension data, and is based on in-depth questionnaires of 166 call centres in 24 countries and five continents.

Title: call centre users 'lose patience'
Sentence: what are your experiences with call centres?

Title: call centre users 'lose patience'
Sentence: are you happy to listen to vivaldi or greensleeves, or do you want an immediate response?

Title: call centre users 'lose patience'
Sentence: and if you work in a call centre: did your training prepare you for your job?

Title: us bank boss hails 'genius' smith
Sentence: us federal reserve chairman alan greenspan has given a speech at a scottish church in honour of the pioneering economist, adam smith.

Title: us bank boss hails 'genius' smith
Sentence: he delivered the 14th adam smith lecture in kirkcaldy, fife.

Title: us bank boss hails 'genius' smith
Sentence: the adam smith lecture celebrates the author of 1776's wealth of nations, which became a bible of capitalism.

Title: us bank boss hails 'genius' smith
Sentence: dr greenspan was invited by chancellor gordon brown, whose minister father john used to preach at the st bryce kirk church.

Title: us bank boss hails 'genius' smith
Sentence: mr brown introduced dr greenspan to the 400 invited guests as the "the world's greatest economist".

Title: us bank boss hails 'genius' smith
Sentence: dr greenspan, 79, who has been in the uk to attend the g7 meeting in london, said the world could never repay the debt of gratitude it owed to smith, whose genius he compared to that of mozart.

Title: us bank boss hails 'genius' smith
Sentence: he said the philosopher was a "towering contributor to the modern world".

Title: us bank boss hails 'genius' smith
Sentence: "kirkcaldy, the birthplace in 1723 of adam smith and, by extension, of modern economics, is also of course, where your chancellor was reared.

Title: us bank boss hails 'genius' smith
Sentence: "i am led to ponder to what extent the chancellor's renowned economic and financial skills are the result of exposure to the subliminal intellect-enhancing emanation in this area."

Title: us bank boss hails 'genius' smith
Sentence: he continued: "smith reached far beyond the insights of his predecessors to frame a global view of how market economics, just then emerging, worked.

Title: us bank boss hails 'genius' smith
Sentence: "in so doing he supported changes in societal organisation that were to measurably enhance standards of living."

Title: us bank boss hails 'genius' smith
Sentence: dr greenspan said smith's revolutionary philosophy on human self-interest, laissez-faire economics and competition had been a force for good in the world.

Title: us bank boss hails 'genius' smith
Sentence: "the incredible insights of a handful of intellectuals of the enlightenment - especially with smith toiling in the environs of kirkcaldy - created the modern vision of people free to choose and to act according to their individual self-interest," he said.

Title: us bank boss hails 'genius' smith
Sentence: following his lecture, dr greenspan - who received an honorary knighthood from the queen at balmoral in 2002 - was awarded an honorary fellowship of the royal society of edinburgh.

Title: us bank boss hails 'genius' smith
Sentence: he later opened an exhibition dedicated to smith in the atrium of fife college of further and higher education.

Title: us bank boss hails 'genius' smith
Sentence: joyce johnston, principal of the college, said: "it is very fitting that the world's premier economist delivered this lecture in tribute to the world's first economist."

Title: us bank boss hails 'genius' smith
Sentence: dr greenspan - who became chairman of the federal reserve for an unprecedented fifth term in june 2004 - will step down in january next year.

Sentence: he has served under presidents george w bush, bill clinton, george bush, and ronald reagan.

Title: us bank boss hails 'genius' smith
Sentence: he was also chairman of the council of economic advisors to gerald ford.

Title: china now top trader with japan
Sentence: china overtook the us to become japan's biggest trading partner in 2004, according to numbers released by japan's finance ministry on wednesday.

Title: china now top trader with japan
Sentence: china accounted for 20.1% of japan's trade in 2004, compared with 18.6% for the us.

Sentence: the change highlights china's growing importance as an economic powerhouse.

Sentence: this is the highest figure for japanese trade with china since records began in 1947. it compares with 20,479.5bn yen in trade with the us.

Sentence: trade with the us during 2004 was hurt by one-off factors, including a 13-month ban on us beef imports following the discovery of a cow infected with mad cow disease (bse) in the us.

Sentence: however, economists predict china will become an even more important japanese trading partner in the coming years.

Title: uk economy ends year with spurt

Sentence: the figure is in line with treasury and bank of england forecasts.

Title: healthsouth ex-boss goes on trial
Sentence: the former head of us medical services firm healthsouth overstated earnings and assets to boost the company's share price, it was claimed in court.

Title: healthsouth ex-boss goes on trial
Sentence: richard scrushy, 52, is accused of "directing" a $2.7bn (â£1.4bn) accounting fraud at the company he co-founded in alabama in 1984. prosecutors said he was motivated by wealth - spending about $200m between 1996 and 2002 while earning much less.

Sentence: defence lawyers said mr scrushy had been deceived by other executives.

Title: healthsouth ex-boss goes on trial
Sentence: mr scrushy is the first chief executive to be tried for breaching the sarbanes oxley act - a law introduced in the wake of the enron and worldcom frauds which obliges corporate bosses to vouch for the accuracy of their companies' results.

Title: euro firms miss out on optimism
Sentence: more than 90% of large companies around the world are highly optimistic about their economic prospects, a survey of 1,300 bosses suggests.

Title: euro firms miss out on optimism
Sentence: their biggest worries are not terror threats, but over-regulation, low-cost competition and the wild ups and downs of oil prices.

Title: euro firms miss out on optimism
Sentence: there is one exception: firms in western europe - but not the uk - are lacking confidence after years of slow growth.

Title: euro firms miss out on optimism
Sentence: when business advisers pricewaterhousecoopers (pwc) conducted the same survey two years ago, nearly 30% of bosses were gloomy about their prospects.

Title: euro firms miss out on optimism
Sentence: global business leaders say that they are facing a two-pronged regulatory assault.

Title: euro firms miss out on optimism
Sentence: after a string of corporate scandals in the united states - from enron to worldcom - the sarbanes-oxley act forces companies to be much more transparent, but doing all the paperwork costs a lot of time and money.

Title: euro firms miss out on optimism
Sentence: across europe, meanwhile, all stock exchange-listed companies are currently in the process of moving to new and complex accounting standards called ifrs.

Title: euro firms miss out on optimism
Sentence: hacking through the red tape can hardly be avoided, but many chief executives around the world appear to have decided on how to deal with low-cost competitors.

Title: euro firms miss out on optimism
Sentence: already, about 28% of the bosses polled for the survey say that they have moved parts of their business into low-wage countries, and another 11% plan to do so in the future.

Title: euro firms miss out on optimism
Sentence: possibly as a result, the worry about low-cost competition has slightly fallen from last year, with just 54% of companies calling it a "significant threat" or "one of the biggest threats".

Title: euro firms miss out on optimism
Sentence: but pwc's global chief executive, samuel dipiazza, said a growing number of companies were also concerned that moves to outsource work to cheaper countries could both hurt their reputation in their home markets and harm the quality of service they provide to their customers.

Title: euro firms miss out on optimism
Sentence: according to frank brown, global advisory leader at pwc , the trend of large companies to have global operations has one clear upside: "one risk in one region - for example the middle east - won't kill your business anymore."

Title: euro firms miss out on optimism
Sentence: surprisingly, the survey suggests that the rapid decline of the us dollar is not seen as a huge threat anymore, unlike even a year ago, when it was cited as the third-largest problem.

Title: euro firms miss out on optimism
Sentence: mr dipiazza said the interviews with chief executives suggested that companies had "adjusted" to the new reality of a euro that buys $1.30 and more, while others had successfully hedged their positions and locked in more favourable exchange rates.

Title: euro firms miss out on optimism
Sentence: - for the survey, pricewaterhousecoopers interviewed 1,324 chief executives throughout the world during the last three months of 2004.
